str2: From hupokrinomai; an actor under an assumed character, i.e. a dissembler
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Lord, master, sir; the Lord. From kuros; supreme in authority, i.e. controller; by implication, Master.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: From apo and krino; to conclude for oneself, i.e. to respond; by Hebraism to begin to speak.
No, not. Also ouk, and ouch a primary word; the absolute negative adverb; no or not.
Each (of more than two), every one. As if a superlative of hekas; each or every.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
The Sabbath, a week.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: A primary verb; to 'loosen'.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Singular
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
An ox, cow, bull. Probably from the base of bosko; an ox, i.e. An animal of that species.
Or, than. A primary particle of distinction between two connected terms; disjunctive, or; comparative, than.
A donkey. Apparently a primary word; a donkey.
From, away from. A primary particle; 'off, ' i.e. Away, in various senses.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
A manger, feeding-trough, stall. From pateomai; a crib.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: To lead, carry, take away; met: To be led astray, seduced. From apo and ago; to take off.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To cause to drink, give to drink; irrigate, water. From a derivative of the alternate of pino; to furnish drink, irrigate.
